comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called historic porch gingerbread & scrollwork, and we'd love to have your photo added to the group.

comment.author: 21042979@N00
comment._content: What a fantastic place! I wonder how long it stood there, and who owned it. The gingerbread trim with the laundry hanging about, and the boarded up window upstairs, is an interesting combination visually and says much about their lives.

comment.author: 79306003@N00
comment._content: Beautiful detail in this photo.

comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Social Documentary Photography & events, and we'd love to have your photo added to the group.

comment.author: 28277802@N00
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Houses with Towers, and we'd love to have your photo added to the group, please. :)

comment.author: 22967417@N07
comment._content: Love those double wrap-around porches!  It's a bit strange that most contemporary homes do not have porches - wonder why they've been out of style for so long...perhaps because so few people walk on sidewalks anymore.

comment.author: 28277802@N00
comment._content: Well, it's mostly, I think, because we have air conditioning now and don't need porches to sit on to cool off.

comment.author: 88187252@N00
comment._content: I kind of remember my Gran calling them "veranda's" and in hot evenings they would put mattresses on the upper's and sleep out of doors.

comment.author: 95722316@N00
comment._content: If I'm reading the curb street sign correct, it's the 1900 block of Franklin, which would put it just north of where Minute Maid Park is now.   I didn't realize how rural that area still was in the 1940s, as it would be considered part of downtown now.

comment.author: 95438463@N00
comment._content: wow that is an awesome slice of the past

comment.author: 23082992@N05
comment._content: It's like the house in The Magnificent Ambersons! Can't you just imagine what a mansion this used to be, in its own estate? then fortunes of the owners diminished, they sold off bits of property ...people built next door - ...little houses...then the family died out or fled...and the house is now a wreck. But you can still tell what a gorgeous and expensive house it once was. "Every flower fades"

comment.author: 11715467@N04
comment._content: Wow, this is wonderful, so much detail and history, I could stare at it for an hour and keep finding new things. glennaa I can definitely make out the 1900 and it looks like it could be Franklin. -- Seen in your 1930s-40s in Color set. (?)

comment.author: 95722316@N00
comment._content: Terrie K , after looking at the B&W photo referenced in the description, it's definitely the 1900 block of Franklin, and it doesn't look so rural - the cross street is pretty busy. -- Seen in my recent comments. (?)

comment.author: 30409516@N00
comment._content: I'm 90% certain this is a house on Heights Blvd which is still standing, and currently very well-maintained.  It's been 2 years since I have lived there and thus could go check the details.

comment.author: 95722316@N00
comment._content: 1900 Franklin would be near where Minute Maid park is now. Actually, if you go to Google Maps and look up 1900 Franklin, Houston Tx, you can get a street view of what the area looks like now. Not much there. -- Seen in my recent comments. (?)

comment.author: 23625856@N08
comment._content: Ahhh, what a simpler time.  I wonder what was eventually built in it's place and if that man could have ever foreseen Houston becoming what it is today- modern chaos!  I would love to know what he thinks about the toll roads and hours upon hours of traffic.

comment.author: 9385421@N08
comment._content:
This is Americana and the way it was when people worked out of their homes.

What a great picture of a bygone era.

comment.author: 21506490@N00
comment._content: I'll bet there's a shiny 25-story office building with 3 levels of underground parking there now.

comment.author: 20698962@N00
comment._content: Actually, no, there's just a parking lot. I took this photograph there. Looks like the slab is still there.

comment.author: 21506490@N00
comment._content:
Cool, but how did you figure out the address??

When I see these old photos, I always wonder how long the building stood, if it's still there, or what is there now, how the neighborhood changed over the decades.

Lived a few years in the "Montrose" area 1984-1990, about four blocks east of Texas Art Supply and Anderson Fair. Are those businesses still there? That neighborhood was mostly old houses with big, covered porches.

comment.author: 20698962@N00
comment._content:
Someone up in the comments said the address.  I don't know how they came about it.

I am not sure about Anderson Fair.  It might be still going,  Texas Art Supply is still there.

I live not far from there in the Heights.

comment.author: 76373900@N02
comment._content: What an awesome old house, it is amazing compared to the cracker box houses they build these days.

comment.author: 9385421@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/76373900@N02] Hollow15 -- Outside its visually inticing, but structurally these houses were not that great. Regular raw untreated lumber was used. No insulation, Single pane glass. No Air Conditioning. Heat was sub-par. Creaky floors & stair cases. Wood sub-floor (built up on footers) over the bare earth. I would prefer todays house to this old one..

comment.author: 11555477@N05
comment._content: It was built in 1939, and I doubt very much that it's standing in 2012.  With as much decorative trim and difficult drainage planes as it has on the roof, maintenance would be entirely too costly to keep up with over time.  Roof leaks would begin to erode it on the interior, and no one would want to own it enough to pay the price of maintaining it.

comment.author: 85140343@N08
comment._content:
Saw the "Pepsi" sign and remembered this from the early forties:
"Pepsi Cola hits the spot
Twelve full ounces, that's a lot
Twice as much for a nickel, too
Pepsi Cola is the drink for you."
I guess Coca Cola came in six ounce bottles in those days.  I was four years old when this jingle was indellibly impressed on my mind.  Except for the fact that I remember the words (and melody) it had no effect.  I hate carbonated beverages.

comment.author: 89673618@N06
comment._content:
Sorry but the wood of years gone by aint the wood of today...Way to much bug infestation.

My grandparent house that my grandfather built(not fancy) is still standing, built in the 40's, even after hurricane of 1989 hit.

Houses now a day are built shoddy, Huff & puff & they all blow down...
